intro: Xylophacos purshii var. leucolobus, commonly known as the white-lipped xylophacos, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and umbel-like inflorescence. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its roots are fibrous and often used in traditional herbal medicine. The species is adapted to dry, rocky soils and is typically found in open woodlands and grasslands.
